Title: Two new species of Aspergillus of the section Flavi
Keywords:
Acetamidase gene, Aspergillus parasiticus,
O-methyltransferase gene, molecular identification, fungal taxonomy
Abstract:
During a survey on the incidence of Aspergillus in
clinical environments, we found some interesting isolates
morphologically similar to Aspergillus parasiticus, but differing from
this species mainly in the color of the colonies and in the conidial
ornamentation. In the present study, those isolates were characterized
using a polyphasic approach. A phylogenetic analysis, based on partial
sequences of the acetamidase (amdS) and O-methyltransferase (omtS) genes
and the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region of rDNA, together with
a detailed morphological and physiological study, which included
aflatoxins production and assimilation profiles of different carbon and
nitrogen sources, were performed. The phenotypic and genotypic results
supported the proposal of two new species, Aspergillus novoparasiticus
and Aspergillus spinosissimus, both phylogenetically related to A.
parasiticus. The former has lobate-reticulate conidia and does not
produce aspergillic acid on AFPA or organic acid on CREA, while A.
parasiticus has echinulate conidia and produces aspergillic and organic
acids. In addition, this new species, as well as A. parasiticus,
produces aflatoxins B1, B2, G1 and G2. Aspergillus spinosissimus differs
from A. parasiticus because the former produces echinulate-lobate
conidia with pyramidal spines, abundant sclerotia, a red diffusible
pigment at 37 C on PDA, and only aflatoxin B1.
